significantly reduces the model's inference latency on edge hardware for
robots. We conducted experiments on downstream tasks to verify the scalability
of our methods. The inference time for detection and segmentation is reduced on
all three hardware types compared to MobileNetv3-based methods. Our work fills
the gap in NAS for robot hardware resource-aware.

AI.tldr: RAM-NAS proposes a resource-aware multi-objective neural architecture search focusing on robotic hardware. It achieves high accuracy and reduced latency compared to existing methods.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address limitations in conventional NAS methods that disregard robot hardware resource constraints and insufficient supernet pretraining processes.
AI.method: RAM-NAS integrates subnets mutual distillation using the sandwich rule and enhances distillation with DKD loss. Latency Surrogate predictors are employed for hardware inference latency estimation during the evolutionary search.
AI.result: RAM-NAS models achieve 76.7%-81.4% top-1 accuracy on ImageNet and reduced inference latency compared to MobileNetv3-based methods on robotic edge hardware.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method bridges the gap in NAS, emphasizing resource-aware optimization tailored to robotic hardware, offering scalability and improved performance on downstream tasks.

title: FS-DFM: Fast and Accurate Long Text Generation with Few-Step Diffusion Language Models
summary:
Autoregressive language models (ARMs) deliver strong likelihoods, but are
inherently serial: they generate one token per forward pass, which limits
throughput and inflates latency for long sequences. Diffusion Language Models
(DLMs) parallelize across positions and thus appear promising for language
generation, yet standard discrete diffusion typically needs hundreds to
thousands of model evaluations to reach high quality, trading serial depth for
iterative breadth. We introduce FS-DFM, Few-Step Discrete Flow-Matching. A
discrete flow-matching model designed for speed without sacrificing quality.
The core idea is simple: make the number of sampling steps an explicit
parameter and train the model to be consistent across step budgets, so one big
move lands where many small moves would. We pair this with a reliable update
rule that moves probability in the right direction without overshooting, and
with strong teacher guidance distilled from long-run trajectories. Together,
these choices make few-step sampling stable, accurate, and easy to control. On
language modeling benchmarks, FS-DFM with 8 sampling steps achieves perplexity
parity with a 1,024-step discrete-flow baseline for generating 1,024 tokens
using a similar-size model, delivering up to 128 times faster sampling and
corresponding latency/throughput gains.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces FS-DFM, a new discrete flow-matching model that drastically reduces the number of sampling steps required in diffusion-based language models, achieving high-quality output up to 128 times faster than traditional methods.
AI.motivation: The motivation of the paper lies in addressing the inefficiencies of autoregressive language models (ARMs) and standard discrete diffusion—which are either serial or excessively iterative—by proposing a method that accelerates language generation while maintaining quality.
AI.method: The authors propose FS-DFM, a flow-matching model trained to be consistent across different sampling step budgets. The design includes an update rule for stable movement of probabilities, and teacher guidance distilled from longer trajectories to ensure accuracy.
AI.result: FS-DFM attains perplexity results comparable to a 1,024-step discrete-flow baseline while only using 8 sampling steps. This approach results in up to 128 times faster sampling with similar-level modeling quality.
AI.conclusion: The proposed FS-DFM enables significant improvements in language generation speed without compromising quality, making it a highly efficient alternative to traditional methods in the space of discrete diffusion models.

title: Enhancing Cross-View Geo-Localization Generalization via Global-Local Consistency and Geometric Equivariance
summary:
Cross-view geo-localization (CVGL) aims to match images of the same location
captured from drastically different viewpoints. Despite recent progress,
existing methods still face two key challenges: (1) achieving robustness under
severe appearance variations induced by diverse UAV orientations and fields of
view, which hinders cross-domain generalization, and (2) establishing reliable
correspondences that capture both global scene-level semantics and fine-grained
local details. In this paper, we propose EGS, a novel CVGL framework designed
to enhance cross-domain generalization. Specifically, we introduce an
E(2)-Steerable CNN encoder to extract stable and reliable features under
rotation and viewpoint shifts. Furthermore, we construct a graph with a virtual
super-node that connects to all local nodes, enabling global semantics to be
aggregated and redistributed to local regions, thereby enforcing global-local
consistency. Extensive experiments on the University-1652 and SUES-200
benchmarks demonstrate that EGS consistently achieves substantial performance
gains and establishes a new state of the art in cross-domain CVGL.

AI.tldr: The paper tackles challenges in cross-view geo-localization by introducing a novel framework to enhance cross-domain generalization.
AI.motivation: To address robustness issues under diverse UAV orientations and establish reliable global and local correspondences in cross-view geo-localization tasks.
AI.method: Introduce EGS framework with E²-Steerable CNN encoder for stable feature extraction and a graph-based mechanism incorporating a virtual super-node for global-local consistency.
AI.result: The proposed EGS framework significantly improved performance compared to previous methods on benchmarks University-1652 and SUES-200.
AI.conclusion: EGS establishes a new state-of-the-art in cross-view geo-localization by overcoming challenges of robustness and correspondence reliability.

title: PIRF: Physics-Informed Reward Fine-Tuning for Diffusion Models
comment: 18 pages, 6 figures; NeurIPS 2025 AI for science workshop
summary:
Diffusion models have demonstrated strong generative capabilities across
scientific domains, but often produce outputs that violate physical laws. We
propose a new perspective by framing physics-informed generation as a sparse
reward optimization problem, where adherence to physical constraints is treated
as a reward signal. This formulation unifies prior approaches under a
reward-based paradigm and reveals a shared bottleneck: reliance on diffusion
posterior sampling (DPS)-style value function approximations, which introduce
non-negligible errors and lead to training instability and inference
inefficiency. To overcome this, we introduce Physics-Informed Reward
Fine-tuning (PIRF), a method that bypasses value approximation by computing
trajectory-level rewards and backpropagating their gradients directly. However,
a naive implementation suffers from low sample efficiency and compromised data
fidelity. PIRF mitigates these issues through two key strategies: (1) a
layer-wise truncated backpropagation method that leverages the spatiotemporally
localized nature of physics-based rewards, and (2) a weight-based
regularization scheme that improves efficiency over traditional
distillation-based methods. Across five PDE benchmarks, PIRF consistently
achieves superior physical enforcement under efficient sampling regimes,
highlighting the potential of reward fine-tuning for advancing scientific
generative modeling.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Physics-Informed Reward Fine-tuning (PIRF), a method for improving physics-informed generative models by optimizing sparse reward signals instead of relying on existing sampling techniques, which often introduce errors.
AI.motivation: Generative models, specifically diffusion models, often fail to adhere to physical laws despite their capabilities. The paper aims to address this limitation by proposing a new perspective for enforcing physical constraints.
AI.method: The paper frames physics-informed generative modeling as a sparse reward optimization problem and introduces PIRF, which avoids reliance on diffusion posterior sampling (DPS). PIRF employs trajectory-level rewards and backpropagation techniques, enhanced by layer-wise truncated backpropagation and weight-based regularization strategies.
AI.result: PIRF demonstrates superior performance across five PDE benchmarks in maintaining physical constraints while ensuring efficiency and sample fidelity.
AI.conclusion: The proposed PIRF method showcases the potential for utilizing reward fine-tuning to advance scientific generative modeling, overcoming limitations like training instability and inefficiency seen in prior methods.

title: Go With The Flow: Churn-Tolerant Decentralized Training of Large Language Models
summary:
Motivated by the emergence of large language models (LLMs) and the importance
of democratizing their training, we propose GWTF, the first crash tolerant
practical decentralized training framework for LLMs. Differently from existing
distributed and federated training frameworks, GWTF enables the efficient
collaborative training of a LLM on heterogeneous clients that volunteer their
resources. In addition, GWTF addresses node churn, i.e., clients joining or
leaving the system at any time, and network instabilities, i.e., network links
becoming unstable or unreliable. The core of GWTF is a novel decentralized flow
algorithm that finds the most effective routing that maximizes the number of
microbatches trained with the lowest possible delay. We extensively evaluate
GWTF on GPT-like and LLaMa-like models and compare it against the prior art.
Our results indicate that GWTF reduces the training time by up to 45% in
realistic and challenging scenarios that involve heterogeneous client nodes
distributed over 10 different geographic locations with a high node churn rate.

AI.tldr: GWTF is a decentralized framework enabling crash-tolerant, collaborative training of LLMs across heterogeneous client nodes, reducing up to 45% training time.
AI.motivation: The need to democratize LLM training while addressing challenges like decentralized, client-driven computations, network instabilities, and node dynamics.
AI.method: Proposes a novel decentralized flow algorithm that ensures efficient microbatch routing and minimizes delay in training on distributed, heterogeneous systems.
AI.result: The framework shows up to 45% training time reduction in scenarios with high node churn and geographic distribution.
AI.conclusion: GWTF is a stepped-forward crash-resistant and practical solution for decentralized LLM training, helping harness diverse and distributed client resources effectively.

title: GALAX: Graph-Augmented Language Model for Explainable Reinforcement-Guided Subgraph Reasoning in Precision Medicine
summary:
In precision medicine, quantitative multi-omic features, topological context,
and textual biological knowledge play vital roles in identifying
disease-critical signaling pathways and targets. Existing pipelines capture
only part of these-numerical omics ignore topological context, text-centric
LLMs lack quantitative grounded reasoning, and graph-only models underuse node
semantics and the generalization of LLMs-limiting mechanistic interpretability.
Although Process Reward Models (PRMs) aim to guide reasoning in LLMs, they
remain limited by unreliable intermediate evaluation, and vulnerability to
reward hacking with computational cost. These gaps motivate integrating
quantitative multi-omic signals, topological structure with node annotations,
and literature-scale text via LLMs, using subgraph reasoning as the principle
bridge linking numeric evidence, topological knowledge and language context.
Therefore, we propose GALAX (Graph Augmented LAnguage model with
eXplainability), an innovative framework that integrates pretrained Graph
Neural Networks (GNNs) into Large Language Models (LLMs) via reinforcement
guided by a Graph Process Reward Model (GPRM), which generates disease-relevant
subgraphs in a step-wise manner initiated by an LLM and iteratively evaluated
by a pretrained GNN, enabling process-level supervision without explicit
intermediate reasoning annotations. As an application, we also introduced
Target-QA, a benchmark combining CRISPR-identified targets, multi-omic
profiles, and biomedical graph knowledge across diverse cancer cell lines,
which enables GNN pretraining for supervising step-wise graph construction and
supports long-context reasoning over text-numeric graphs (TNGs), providing a
scalable and biologically grounded framework for explainable,
reinforcement-guided subgraph reasoning toward reliable and interpretable
target and pathway discovery in precision medicine.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces GALAX, a framework integrating Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) into Large Language Models (LLMs) to improve disease pathway identification and target discovery in precision medicine using subgraph reasoning. A benchmark, Target-QA, validates the approach.
AI.motivation: Existing methods in precision medicine fail to combine quantitative multi-omic signals, topological contexts, and textual biological knowledge comprehensively, resulting in limitations in mechanistic interpretability.
AI.method: The proposed GALAX framework integrates pretrained GNNs into LLMs using reinforcement guided by a Graph Process Reward Model to create disease-relevant subgraphs step-wise. Target-QA benchmark is introduced for evaluation.
AI.result: GALAX enables process-level supervision for graph construction without intermediate reasoning annotations, combining numeric, topological, and textual data for identifying pathways and targets.
AI.conclusion: GALAX demonstrates scalable, explainable reasoning capabilities for precision medicine by integrating diverse datasets and mechanism-driven subgraph reasoning, offering a robust framework for target discovery.

title: Fine-Tuning LLMs to Analyze Multiple Dimensions of Code Review: A Maximum Entropy Regulated Long Chain-of-Thought Approach
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown great potential in supporting
automated code review due to their impressive capabilities in context
understanding and reasoning. However, these capabilities are still limited
compared to human-level cognition because they are heavily influenced by the
training data. Recent research has demonstrated significantly improved
performance through fine-tuning LLMs with code review data. However, compared
to human reviewers who often simultaneously analyze multiple dimensions of code
review to better identify issues, the full potential of these methods is
hampered by the limited or vague information used to fine-tune the models. This
paper contributes MelcotCR, a chain-of-thought (COT) fine-tuning approach that
trains LLMs with an impressive reasoning ability to analyze multiple dimensions
of code review by harnessing long COT techniques to provide rich structured
information. To address context loss and reasoning logic loss issues that
frequently occur when LLMs process long COT prompts, we propose a solution that
combines the Maximum Entropy (ME) modeling principle with pre-defined reasoning
pathways in MelcotCR to enable more effective utilization of in-context
knowledge within long COT prompts while strengthening the logical tightness of
the reasoning process. Empirical evaluations on our curated MelcotCR dataset
and the public CodeReviewer dataset reveal that a low-parameter base model,
such as 14B Qwen2.5, fine-tuned with MelcotCR can surpass state-of-the-art
methods in terms of the accuracy of detecting and describing code issues, with
its performance remarkably on par with that of the 671B DeepSeek-R1 model.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MelcotCR, a chain-of-thought fine-tuning approach for large language models (LLMs) to improve automated code review by facilitating reasoning across multiple dimensions of code analysis.
AI.motivation: LLMs are promising for code review but fall short compared to human reviewers due to limited reasoning capabilities and insufficient fine-tuning data.
AI.method: The authors propose MelcotCR, leveraging chain-of-thought fine-tuning and the Maximum Entropy modeling principle to fine-tune LLMs for reasoning across multiple dimensions using structured prompts.
AI.result: Empirical evaluations show that a low-parameter base model like 14B Qwen2.5 trained with MelcotCR exceeds state-of-the-art methods in identifying code issues, performing comparably to much larger models like 671B DeepSeek-R1.
AI.conclusion: MelcotCR enhances the efficiency and accuracy of LLMs in code reviews, showing the potential of specialized fine-tuning with structured reasoning approaches to match or exceed state-of-the-art outcomes.

title: Learning Ising Models under Hard Constraints using One Sample
summary:
We consider the problem of estimating inverse temperature parameter $\beta$
of an $n$-dimensional truncated Ising model using a single sample. Given a
graph $G = (V,E)$ with $n$ vertices, a truncated Ising model is a probability
distribution over the $n$-dimensional hypercube $\{-1,1\}^n$ where each
configuration $\mathbf{\sigma}$ is constrained to lie in a truncation set $S
\subseteq \{-1,1\}^n$ and has probability $\Pr(\mathbf{\sigma}) \propto
\exp(\beta\mathbf{\sigma}^\top A\mathbf{\sigma})$ with $A$ being the adjacency
matrix of $G$. We adopt the recent setting of [Galanis et al. SODA'24], where
the truncation set $S$ can be expressed as the set of satisfying assignments of
a $k$-SAT formula. Given a single sample $\mathbf{\sigma}$ from a truncated
Ising model, with inverse parameter $\beta^*$, underlying graph $G$ of bounded
degree $\Delta$ and $S$ being expressed as the set of satisfying assignments of
a $k$-SAT formula, we design in nearly $O(n)$ time an estimator $\hat{\beta}$
that is $O(\Delta^3/\sqrt{n})$-consistent with the true parameter $\beta^*$ for
$k \gtrsim \log(d^2k)\Delta^3.$
  Our estimator is based on the maximization of the pseudolikelihood, a notion
that has received extensive analysis for various probabilistic models without
[Chatterjee, Annals of Statistics '07] or with truncation [Galanis et al. SODA
'24]. Our approach generalizes recent techniques from [Daskalakis et al. STOC
'19, Galanis et al. SODA '24], to confront the more challenging setting of the
truncated Ising model.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the problem of estimating the inverse temperature parameter β of a truncated Ising model, where configurations are constrained by a k-SAT formula, using a single sample. An estimator is proposed with nearly O(n) computational time, showcasing strong consistency under specific constraints.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to develop computationally efficient estimators for parameters of probabilistic models like truncated Ising models, which are constrained by k-SAT formulas and can model complex systems with dependencies.
AI.method: The paper introduces a nearly O(n)-time estimator for β estimation based on maximizing the pseudolikelihood function. Techniques are built on and extend recent frameworks used for probabilistic models with and without truncations.
AI.result: The estimator is shown to be O(Δ³/√n)-consistent with the true β* under certain conditions, such as bounded graph degree Δ and specific k-SAT relationships. The findings address computational and theoretical challenges in the model.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method provides an efficient and consistent estimator for β in truncated Ising models constrained by k-SAT formulas. It contributes to the understanding and computational tools for complex probabilistic models.

title: Incorporating Human-Inspired Ankle Characteristics in a Forced-Oscillation-Based Reduced-Order Model for Walking
summary:
This paper extends the forced-oscillation-based reduced-order model of
walking to a model with ankles and feet. A human-inspired paradigm was designed
for the ankle dynamics, which results in improved gait characteristics compared
to the point-foot model. In addition, it was shown that while the proposed
model can stabilize against large errors in initial conditions through
combination of foot placement and ankle strategies, the model is able to
stabilize against small perturbations without relying on the foot placement
control and solely through the designed proprioceptive ankle scheme. This novel
property, which is also observed in humans, can help in better understanding of
anthropomorphic walking and its stabilization mechanisms.

AI.tldr: This paper develops a walking model incorporating ankle dynamics to improve gait stability and mimic human stabilization strategies.
AI.motivation: Existing reduced-order walking models lack dynamics for ankles and feet, limiting their ability to accurately represent human gait and stabilization behaviors.
AI.method: By adapting a human-inspired paradigm for ankle dynamics, the model combines foot placement and proprioceptive ankle control strategies to enhance walking stability.
AI.result: The upgraded model stabilizes against large initial errors using foot placement and ankle strategies, and addresses small perturbations using solely ankle dynamics.
AI.conclusion: The model provides insights into anthropomorphic walking, particularly stabilization mechanisms observed in humans.

title: Look Before you Leap: Estimating LLM Benchmark Scores from Descriptions
summary:
Progress in large language models is constrained by an evaluation bottleneck:
build a benchmark, evaluate models and settings, then iterate. We therefore ask
a simple question: can we forecast outcomes before running any experiments? We
study text-only performance forecasting: estimating a model's score from a
redacted task description and intended configuration, with no access to dataset
instances. To support systematic study, we curate PRECOG, a corpus of redacted
description-performance pairs spanning diverse tasks, domains, and metrics.
Experiments show the task is challenging but feasible: models equipped with a
retrieval module that excludes source papers achieve moderate prediction
performance with well-calibrated uncertainty, reaching mean absolute error as
low as 8.7 on the Accuracy subset at high-confidence thresholds. Our analysis
indicates that stronger reasoning models engage in diverse, iterative querying,
whereas current open-source models lag and often skip retrieval or gather
evidence with limited diversity. We further test a zero-leakage setting,
forecasting on newly released datasets or experiments before their papers are
indexed, where GPT-5 with built-in web search still attains nontrivial
prediction accuracy. Overall, our corpus and analyses offer an initial step
toward open-ended anticipatory evaluation, supporting difficulty estimation and
smarter experiment prioritization.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a method to forecast large language model performance from redacted task descriptions without dataset access, using the PRECOG benchmark. It achieves moderate prediction accuracy and proposes improvements for anticipatory evaluations.
AI.motivation: Evaluating large language models is time-consuming and resource-intensive due to the need to build benchmarks and run experiments iteratively. The work explores if it’s possible to predict performance before conducting any trials.
AI.method: They create a dataset (PRECOG) with redacted task description-performance pairs and experiment with models that use retrieval modules for performance prediction. Zero-leakage testing is also conducted on unindexed datasets.
AI.result: Their model achieves mean absolute error as low as 8.7 on accuracy benchmarks. They show that stronger reasoning models diversify and iteratively query to gather evidence, while current models exhibit limited querying abilities.
AI.conclusion: Their corpus facilitates the exploration of anticipatory evaluation in large language model research, allowing smarter experiment prioritization and task difficulty estimation in advance.

title: DENet: Dual-Path Edge Network with Global-Local Attention for Infrared Small Target Detection
summary:
Infrared small target detection is crucial for remote sensing applications
like disaster warning and maritime surveillance. However, due to the lack of
distinctive texture and morphological features, infrared small targets are
highly susceptible to blending into cluttered and noisy backgrounds. A
fundamental challenge in designing deep models for this task lies in the
inherent conflict between capturing high-resolution spatial details for minute
targets and extracting robust semantic context for larger targets, often
leading to feature misalignment and suboptimal performance. Existing methods
often rely on fixed gradient operators or simplistic attention mechanisms,
which are inadequate for accurately extracting target edges under low contrast
and high noise. In this paper, we propose a novel Dual-Path Edge Network that
explicitly addresses this challenge by decoupling edge enhancement and semantic
modeling into two complementary processing paths. The first path employs a
Bidirectional Interaction Module, which uses both Local Self-Attention and
Global Self-Attention to capture multi-scale local and global feature
dependencies. The global attention mechanism, based on a Transformer
architecture, integrates long-range semantic relationships and contextual
information, ensuring robust scene understanding. The second path introduces
the Multi-Edge Refiner, which enhances fine-grained edge details using cascaded
Taylor finite difference operators at multiple scales. This mathematical
approach, along with an attention-driven gating mechanism, enables precise edge
localization and feature enhancement for targets of varying sizes, while
effectively suppressing noise. Our method provides a promising solution for
precise infrared small target detection and localization, combining structural
semantics and edge refinement in a unified framework.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a Dual-Path Edge Network to improve infrared small target detection under cluttered backgrounds by combining edge enhancement and semantic modeling.
AI.motivation: Infrared small targets are hard to detect due to blending into noisy backgrounds and the lack of distinct features.
AI.method: The method uses two paths: 1) Bidirectional Interaction Module for semantic understanding and 2) Multi-Edge Refiner for enhancing edge details using math-based operators and attention mechanisms.
AI.result: It achieves precise small target detection by integrating structural semantics and refined edge details.
AI.conclusion: The framework effectively tackles the challenges in detecting infrared small targets by combining complementary methodologies for improved accuracy and robustness.

title: SuperOffload: Unleashing the Power of Large-Scale LLM Training on Superchips
summary:
The emergence of Superchips represents a significant advancement in
next-generation AI hardware. These Superchips employ a tightly coupled
heterogeneous architecture that integrates GPU and CPU on the same package,
which offers unprecedented computational power. However, there has been scant
research investigating how LLM training benefits from this new architecture. In
this work, for the first time, we study LLM training solutions based on
offloading for Superchips. We observe important differences between Superchips
and traditional loosely-coupled GPU-CPU architecture, which necessitate
revisiting prevailing assumptions about offloading. Based on that, we present
SuperOffload, a Superchip-centric offloading system that simultaneously uses
Hopper GPU, Grace CPU, and NVLink-C2C interconnect more efficiently.
SuperOffload accomplishes this via a combination of techniques, such as
adaptive weight offloading, bucketization repartitioning, Superchip-aware
casting, speculative execution, and a highly optimized Adam optimizer for Grace
CPUs. Our evaluation of SuperOffload on NVIDIA GH200 demonstrates up to 2.5x
throughput improvement compared to state-of-the-art offloading-based systems,
enabling training of up to 25B model on a single Superchip while achieving high
training throughput. We also extend SuperOffload with ZeRO-style data
parallelism and DeepSpeed-Ulysses sequence parallelism, enabling training of
13B model with sequence lengths up to 1 million tokens on 8 GH200 while
achieving 55% MFU.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces SuperOffload, a system optimized for training large language models (LLMs) on Superchips, achieving up to 2.5x throughput improvement over state-of-the-art systems.
AI.motivation: With the advent of tightly coupled heterogeneous architectures in Superchips (integrating GPU and CPU), there is limited research on how such designs impact large language model (LLM) training. This work aims to explore this gap.
AI.method: The study introduces SuperOffload, an offloading system tailored for Superchips, leveraging techniques like adaptive weight offloading, bucketization repartitioning, Superchip-aware casting, speculative execution, and optimized Adam optimizer. It efficiently uses Hopper GPU, Grace CPU, and NVLink-C2C interconnect.
AI.result: SuperOffload achieves up to 2.5x throughput improvement compared to traditional offloading systems, supporting the training of up to 25B models on a single NVIDIA GH200 Superchip. It also supports ZeRO-style data parallelism and sequence parallelism for extended capabilities.
AI.conclusion: SuperOffload showcases the potential of tailored systems to effectively leverage Superchip architectures, unlocking significant performance gains in LLM training.

title: Beyond Stars: Bridging the Gap Between Ratings and Review Sentiment with LLM
comment:
Paper accepted for presentation at ACS/IEEE 22nd International
  Conference on Computer Systems and Applications (AICCSA 2025)
summary:
We present an advanced approach to mobile app review analysis aimed at
addressing limitations inherent in traditional star-rating systems. Star
ratings, although intuitive and popular among users, often fail to capture the
nuanced feedback present in detailed review texts. Traditional NLP techniques
-- such as lexicon-based methods and classical machine learning classifiers --
struggle to interpret contextual nuances, domain-specific terminology, and
subtle linguistic features like sarcasm. To overcome these limitations, we
propose a modular framework leveraging large language models (LLMs) enhanced by
structured prompting techniques. Our method quantifies discrepancies between
numerical ratings and textual sentiment, extracts detailed, feature-level
insights, and supports interactive exploration of reviews through
retrieval-augmented conversational question answering (RAG-QA). Comprehensive
experiments conducted on three diverse datasets (AWARE, Google Play, and
Spotify) demonstrate that our LLM-driven approach significantly surpasses
baseline methods, yielding improved accuracy, robustness, and actionable
insights in challenging and context-rich review scenarios.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a modular approach using large language models (LLMs) to improve mobile app review analysis by capturing nuanced textual feedback and addressing the limitations of star-rating systems.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the inadequacy of traditional star-rating systems and NLP methods in interpreting contextual and nuanced feedback in app reviews.
AI.method: The study develops a modular framework with LLMs combined with structured prompting techniques. It analyzes textual ratings, extracts feature-level insights, and integrates retrieval-augmented conversational question answering (RAG-QA).
AI.result: The proposed framework outperforms traditional NLP methods across three datasets, demonstrating improved accuracy, robustness, and actionable insights in understanding app reviews.
AI.conclusion: The LLM-driven approach provides a more nuanced, accurate, and effective analysis of app reviews, making it a valuable tool for understanding user feedback in complex contexts.

title: Semantic Clustering of Civic Proposals: A Case Study on Brazil's National Participation Platform
summary:
Promoting participation on digital platforms such as Brasil Participativo has
emerged as a top priority for governments worldwide. However, due to the sheer
volume of contributions, much of this engagement goes underutilized, as
organizing it presents significant challenges: (1) manual classification is
unfeasible at scale; (2) expert involvement is required; and (3) alignment with
official taxonomies is necessary. In this paper, we introduce an approach that
combines BERTopic with seed words and automatic validation by large language
models. Initial results indicate that the generated topics are coherent and
institutionally aligned, with minimal human effort. This methodology enables
governments to transform large volumes of citizen input into actionable data
for public policy.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a combined approach of BERTopic, seed words, and large language models for processing citizen input on digital platforms, addressing challenges with manual classification and taxonomy alignment.
AI.motivation: Governments face challenges in organizing vast contributions on digital platforms, including inefficiency of manual classification, need for expert input, and necessity for aligning with official taxonomies.
AI.method: The methodology combines the BERTopic technique, integration of seed words, and automated validation using large language models to classify and organize citizen input.
AI.result: Initial findings demonstrate that the generated topics are coherent, institutionally aligned, and require minimal human intervention.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach could help governments efficiently turn massive citizen contributions into actionable insights for public policy.

title: Efficient Ensemble Conditional Independence Test Framework for Causal Discovery
summary:
Constraint-based causal discovery relies on numerous conditional independence
tests (CITs), but its practical applicability is severely constrained by the
prohibitive computational cost, especially as CITs themselves have high time
complexity with respect to the sample size. To address this key bottleneck, we
introduce the Ensemble Conditional Independence Test (E-CIT), a general and
plug-and-play framework. E-CIT operates on an intuitive divide-and-aggregate
strategy: it partitions the data into subsets, applies a given base CIT
independently to each subset, and aggregates the resulting p-values using a
novel method grounded in the properties of stable distributions. This framework
reduces the computational complexity of a base CIT to linear in the sample size
when the subset size is fixed. Moreover, our tailored p-value combination
method offers theoretical consistency guarantees under mild conditions on the
subtests. Experimental results demonstrate that E-CIT not only significantly
reduces the computational burden of CITs and causal discovery but also achieves
competitive performance. Notably, it exhibits an improvement in complex testing
scenarios, particularly on real-world datasets.

AI.tldr: E-CIT reduces computational complexity in causal discovery by dividing data subsets, performing tests, and aggregating results using stable distributions.
AI.motivation: Current constraint-based causal discovery methods are computationally expensive due to high-cost conditional independence tests (CITs).
AI.method: Introduce the E-CIT framework, which uses divide-and-aggregate strategies to partition datasets, apply base CITs, and combine results with a stable distribution-based method.
AI.result: E-CIT lowers computational costs to a linear scale while maintaining theoretical consistency and showing robust performance, especially on real-world datasets.
AI.conclusion: E-CIT enhances the practicality of constraint-based causal discovery with efficient and theoretically sound methods.

title: RuN: Residual Policy for Natural Humanoid Locomotion
summary:
Enabling humanoid robots to achieve natural and dynamic locomotion across a
wide range of speeds, including smooth transitions from walking to running,
presents a significant challenge. Existing deep reinforcement learning methods
typically require the policy to directly track a reference motion, forcing a
single policy to simultaneously learn motion imitation, velocity tracking, and
stability maintenance. To address this, we introduce RuN, a novel decoupled
residual learning framework. RuN decomposes the control task by pairing a
pre-trained Conditional Motion Generator, which provides a kinematically
natural motion prior, with a reinforcement learning policy that learns a
lightweight residual correction to handle dynamical interactions. Experiments
in simulation and reality on the Unitree G1 humanoid robot demonstrate that RuN
achieves stable, natural gaits and smooth walk-run transitions across a broad
velocity range (0-2.5 m/s), outperforming state-of-the-art methods in both
training efficiency and final performance.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces RuN, a framework allowing humanoid robots to achieve smooth and dynamic walking-to-running transitions efficiently.
AI.motivation: Enable humanoid robots to perform natural, dynamic locomotion across diverse speeds, overcoming challenges in existing RL methods.
AI.method: Propose RuN, a decoupled residual learning framework using a Conditional Motion Generator for motion prior and reinforcement learning for dynamic corrections.
AI.result: RuN achieves stable and natural gaits with smooth transitions from walk to run, outperforming existing methods in efficiency and performance.
AI.conclusion: RuN effectively resolves locomotion challenges, offering a novel and high-performing solution for humanoid robots across varying speeds.

title: Building Tailored Speech Recognizers for Japanese Speaking Assessment
summary:
This paper presents methods for building speech recognizers tailored for
Japanese speaking assessment tasks. Specifically, we build a speech recognizer
that outputs phonemic labels with accent markers. Although Japanese is
resource-rich, there is only a small amount of data for training models to
produce accurate phonemic transcriptions that include accent marks. We propose
two methods to mitigate data sparsity. First, a multitask training scheme
introduces auxiliary loss functions to estimate orthographic text labels and
pitch patterns of the input signal, so that utterances with only orthographic
annotations can be leveraged in training. The second fuses two estimators, one
over phonetic alphabet strings, and the other over text token sequences. To
combine these estimates we develop an algorithm based on the finite-state
transducer framework. Our results indicate that the use of multitask learning
and fusion is effective for building an accurate phonemic recognizer. We show
that this approach is advantageous compared to the use of generic multilingual
recognizers. The relative advantages of the proposed methods were also
compared. Our proposed methods reduced the average of mora-label error rates
from 12.3% to 7.1% over the CSJ core evaluation sets.

AI.tldr: This study develops methods for creating speech recognizers for Japanese speaking assessments by addressing data sparsity through multitask learning and model fusion, resulting in significant mora-label error rate reduction.
AI.motivation: Japanese speaking assessments require accurate phonemic transcriptions with accent markers, but limited annotated data makes achieving high accuracy challenging.
AI.method: Two methods were proposed: (1) multitask training with auxiliary loss functions to utilize partially annotated data, and (2) fusion of phonetic and text-based estimators using a finite-state transducer framework.
AI.result: The proposed methods significantly reduced mora-label error rates from 12.3% to 7.1% on the CSJ core evaluation sets, outperforming generic multilingual recognizers.
AI.conclusion: The combination of multitask learning and fusion methods effectively enhances phonemic recognition accuracy for Japanese speaking assessment tasks.

title: Beyond the Individual: Introducing Group Intention Forecasting with SHOT Dataset
summary:
Intention recognition has traditionally focused on individual intentions,
overlooking the complexities of collective intentions in group settings. To
address this limitation, we introduce the concept of group intention, which
represents shared goals emerging through the actions of multiple individuals,
and Group Intention Forecasting (GIF), a novel task that forecasts when group
intentions will occur by analyzing individual actions and interactions before
the collective goal becomes apparent. To investigate GIF in a specific
scenario, we propose SHOT, the first large-scale dataset for GIF, consisting of
1,979 basketball video clips captured from 5 camera views and annotated with 6
types of individual attributes. SHOT is designed with 3 key characteristics:
multi-individual information, multi-view adaptability, and multi-level
intention, making it well-suited for studying emerging group intentions.
Furthermore, we introduce GIFT (Group Intention ForecasTer), a framework that
extracts fine-grained individual features and models evolving group dynamics to
forecast intention emergence. Experimental results confirm the effectiveness of
SHOT and GIFT, establishing a strong foundation for future research in group
intention forecasting. The dataset is available at
https://xinyi-hu.github.io/SHOT_DATASET.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces the concept of group intention forecasting (GIF), presents a new dataset SHOT for studying it, and proposes a framework called GIFT for prediction.
AI.motivation: Current intention recognition focuses on individual actions, neglecting how collective goals arise through interactions in a group setting.
AI.method: They propose a new dataset (SHOT) designed to capture group intention dynamics and introduce GIFT, a framework that examines individual and group-level behavior to improve forecasting accuracy.
AI.result: Experimental results show SHOT and GIFT successfully predict group intentions, demonstrating their robustness and setting a baseline for future studies.
AI.conclusion: SHOT and GIFT provide crucial tools for advancing the study of group intention forecasting, opening pathways for innovative research in scenarios needing collective behavior understanding.

title: Learning Greens Operators through Hierarchical Neural Networks Inspired by the Fast Multipole Method
comment:
Previously under review at ICLR 2025, originally submitted on the
  12th of May 2025. The OpenReview page can be found at:
  http://openreview.net/forum?id=QHJb2Q7ONx
summary:
The Fast Multipole Method (FMM) is an efficient numerical algorithm for
computation of long-ranged forces in $N$-body problems within gravitational and
electrostatic fields. This method utilizes multipole expansions of the Green's
function inherent to the underlying dynamical systems. Despite its widespread
application in physics and engineering, the integration of FMM with modern
machine learning architectures remains underexplored. In this work, we propose
a novel neural network architecture, the Neural FMM, that integrates the
information flow of the FMM into a hierarchical machine learning framework for
learning the Green's operator of an Elliptic PDE. Our Neural FMM architecture
leverages a hierarchical computation flow of the FMM method to split up the
local and far-field interactions and efficiently learn their respective
representations.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes the Neural FMM, a new neural network architecture combining the Fast Multipole Method (FMM) with machine learning to learn the Green's operator of Elliptic PDEs.
AI.motivation: The work seeks to explore the under-investigated integration of classical FMM, which efficiently computes long-ranged forces, with modern machine learning models.
AI.method: The authors designed the Neural FMM, blending the hierarchical computation structure of FMM with a learning framework for local and far-field interaction representations.
AI.result: No specific results are described in the abstract, but the method appears to effectively utilize FMM’s hierarchical structure for machine learning applications.
AI.conclusion: The approach establishes a new direction for combining classical numerical methods like FMM with machine learning to address physical problems such as learning the Green's operator.

title: AOT*: Efficient Synthesis Planning via LLM-Empowered AND-OR Tree Search
summary:
Retrosynthesis planning enables the discovery of viable synthetic routes for
target molecules, playing a crucial role in domains like drug discovery and
materials design. Multi-step retrosynthetic planning remains computationally
challenging due to exponential search spaces and inference costs. While Large
Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate chemical reasoning capabilities, their
application to synthesis planning faces constraints on efficiency and cost. To
address these challenges, we introduce AOT*, a framework that transforms
retrosynthetic planning by integrating LLM-generated chemical synthesis
pathways with systematic AND-OR tree search. To this end, AOT* atomically maps
the generated complete synthesis routes onto AND-OR tree components, with a
mathematically sound design of reward assignment strategy and retrieval-based
context engineering, thus enabling LLMs to efficiently navigate in the chemical
space. Experimental evaluation on multiple synthesis benchmarks demonstrates
that AOT* achieves SOTA performance with significantly improved search
efficiency. AOT* exhibits competitive solve rates using 3-5$\times$ fewer
iterations than existing LLM-based approaches, with the efficiency advantage
becoming more pronounced on complex molecular targets.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces AOT*, a framework combining LLMs with AND-OR tree search for more efficient retrosynthesis planning, achieving state-of-the-art results with fewer iterations.
AI.motivation: Retrosynthesis planning is crucial for drug discovery and materials design but faces computational challenges due to large search spaces and inefficiency in current methods.
AI.method: The method involves integrating LLM-generated synthesis pathways with AND-OR tree search, featuring optimized reward strategies and retrieval-based context engineering.
AI.result: Experimental benchmarks show AOT* achieves competitive solve rates with 3-5x fewer iterations compared to existing methods, especially for complex molecules.
AI.conclusion: AOT* significantly improves retrosynthesis planning efficiency and demonstrates state-of-the-art performance, emphasizing its potential for handling complex chemical targets.

title: Inverse Reinforcement Learning Using Just Classification and a Few Regressions
summary:
Inverse reinforcement learning (IRL) aims to explain observed behavior by
uncovering an underlying reward. In the maximum-entropy or
Gumbel-shocks-to-reward frameworks, this amounts to fitting a reward function
and a soft value function that together satisfy the soft Bellman consistency
condition and maximize the likelihood of observed actions. While this
perspective has had enormous impact in imitation learning for robotics and
understanding dynamic choices in economics, practical learning algorithms often
involve delicate inner-loop optimization, repeated dynamic programming, or
adversarial training, all of which complicate the use of modern, highly
expressive function approximators like neural nets and boosting. We revisit
softmax IRL and show that the population maximum-likelihood solution is
characterized by a linear fixed-point equation involving the behavior policy.
This observation reduces IRL to two off-the-shelf supervised learning problems:
probabilistic classification to estimate the behavior policy, and iterative
regression to solve the fixed point. The resulting method is simple and modular
across function approximation classes and algorithms. We provide a precise
characterization of the optimal solution, a generic oracle-based algorithm,
finite-sample error bounds, and empirical results showing competitive or
superior performance to MaxEnt IRL.

AI.tldr: The paper revisits softmax Inverse Reinforcement Learning (IRL), simplifying it into two supervised learning tasks: probabilistic classification and regression, offering a modular and efficient approach.
AI.motivation: Address the complexity of existing IRL methods that hinder the adoption of modern function approximators like neural networks.
AI.method: Reduction of IRL to solving two supervised learning problems: estimating the behavior policy via probabilistic classification and applying iterative regression to solve a fixed-point equation.
AI.result: Presented a modular and simple method with finite-sample error bounds and empirically demonstrated superior or competitive performance compared to MaxEnt IRL.
AI.conclusion: The proposed approach simplifies IRL and facilitates the use of modern function approximation techniques, maintaining or improving performance.

title: Joint Flow Trajectory Optimization For Feasible Robot Motion Generation from Video Demonstrations
summary:
Learning from human video demonstrations offers a scalable alternative to
teleoperation or kinesthetic teaching, but poses challenges for robot
manipulators due to embodiment differences and joint feasibility constraints.
We address this problem by proposing the Joint Flow Trajectory Optimization
(JFTO) framework for grasp pose generation and object trajectory imitation
under the video-based Learning-from-Demonstration (LfD) paradigm. Rather than
directly imitating human hand motions, our method treats demonstrations as
object-centric guides, balancing three objectives: (i) selecting a feasible
grasp pose, (ii) generating object trajectories consistent with demonstrated
motions, and (iii) ensuring collision-free execution within robot kinematics.
To capture the multimodal nature of demonstrations, we extend flow matching to
$\SE(3)$ for probabilistic modeling of object trajectories, enabling
density-aware imitation that avoids mode collapse. The resulting optimization
integrates grasp similarity, trajectory likelihood, and collision penalties
into a unified differentiable objective. We validate our approach in both
simulation and real-world experiments across diverse real-world manipulation
tasks.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a framework called Joint Flow Trajectory Optimization (JFTO) to enable video-based Learning-from-Demonstration (LfD) for robot manipulators. It addresses challenges related to embodiment differences and joint feasibility constraints.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to provide an alternative way for robot manipulators to learn from human demonstrations in video form, which is more scalable than teleoperation or kinesthetic teaching. This approach needs to address embodiment differences between humans and robots as well as feasibility and collision constraints.
AI.method: The JFTO framework focuses on object-centric demonstrations rather than direct replication of human motions. It uses a probabilistic model to represent multimodal object trajectories and balances grasp pose feasibility, trajectory imitation, and collision-free execution via a differentiable optimization framework.
AI.result: The proposed method was validated through simulation and real-world experiments, demonstrating its effectiveness across diverse real-world manipulation tasks.
AI.conclusion: The JFTO framework provides a robust solution for robot manipulators to imitate human demonstrations by focusing on object-centric trajectories and integrating probabilistic modeling into the optimization process, ensuring feasibility and collision avoidance.

title: Enhancing Molecular Property Prediction with Knowledge from Large Language Models
summary:
Predicting molecular properties is a critical component of drug discovery.
Recent advances in deep learning, particularly Graph Neural Networks (GNNs),
have enabled end-to-end learning from molecular structures, reducing reliance
on manual feature engineering. However, while GNNs and self-supervised learning
approaches have advanced molecular property prediction (MPP), the integration
of human prior knowledge remains indispensable, as evidenced by recent methods
that leverage large language models (LLMs) for knowledge extraction. Despite
their strengths, LLMs are constrained by knowledge gaps and hallucinations,
particularly for less-studied molecular properties. In this work, we propose a
novel framework that, for the first time, integrates knowledge extracted from
LLMs with structural features derived from pre-trained molecular models to
enhance MPP. Our approach prompts LLMs to generate both domain-relevant
knowledge and executable code for molecular vectorization, producing
knowledge-based features that are subsequently fused with structural
representations. We employ three state-of-the-art LLMs, GPT-4o, GPT-4.1, and
DeepSeek-R1, for knowledge extraction. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
our integrated method outperforms existing approaches, confirming that the
combination of LLM-derived knowledge and structural information provides a
robust and effective solution for MPP.

AI.tldr: This paper integrates knowledge from large language models (LLMs) with structural representations from pre-trained molecular models to improve molecular property prediction (MPP), achieving better results than existing methods.
AI.motivation: The study aims to improve molecular property prediction (MPP) by addressing limitations in existing methods, such as relying heavily on either graph neural networks (GNNs) or large language models (LLMs) separate from molecular structural data.
AI.method: The proposed framework prompts LLMs to generate both domain knowledge and code for molecular vectorization. This knowledge-based feature is fused with structural features derived from pre-trained molecular models using state-of-the-art LLMs such as GPT-4o, GPT-4.1, and DeepSeek-R1.
AI.result: The integrated approach combining LLM-derived knowledge and molecular structural information significantly outperformed traditional methods across extensive experiments.
AI.conclusion: Integrating LLM-extracted knowledge with structural molecular features provides an effective way to enhance MPP, demonstrating the value of combining human-like knowledge extraction with data-driven approaches.

title: Neptune-X: Active X-to-Maritime Generation for Universal Maritime Object Detection
summary:
Maritime object detection is essential for navigation safety, surveillance,
and autonomous operations, yet constrained by two key challenges: the scarcity
of annotated maritime data and poor generalization across various maritime
attributes (e.g., object category, viewpoint, location, and imaging
environment). % In particular, models trained on existing datasets often
underperform in underrepresented scenarios such as open-sea environments. To
address these challenges, we propose Neptune-X, a data-centric
generative-selection framework that enhances training effectiveness by
leveraging synthetic data generation with task-aware sample selection. From the
generation perspective, we develop X-to-Maritime, a multi-modality-conditioned
generative model that synthesizes diverse and realistic maritime scenes. A key
component is the Bidirectional Object-Water Attention module, which captures
boundary interactions between objects and their aquatic surroundings to improve
visual fidelity. To further improve downstream tasking performance, we propose
Attribute-correlated Active Sampling, which dynamically selects synthetic
samples based on their task relevance. To support robust benchmarking, we
construct the Maritime Generation Dataset, the first dataset tailored for
generative maritime learning, encompassing a wide range of semantic conditions.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach sets a new benchmark in
maritime scene synthesis, significantly improving detection accuracy,
particularly in challenging and previously underrepresented settings.The code
is available at https://github.com/gy65896/Neptune-X.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Neptune-X, a framework utilizing synthetic data generation and active sample selection to improve maritime object detection, addressing issues with data scarcity and generalization.
AI.motivation: Existing models for maritime object detection struggle due to a lack of annotated data and poor performance in diverse and challenging conditions.
AI.method: The proposed method includes a generative model (X-to-Maritime) with a Bidirectional Object-Water Attention module to synthesize realistic scenes and an Attribute-correlated Active Sampling technique to select task-relevant samples dynamically.
AI.result: Experiments showcase improved maritime scene synthesis and a new benchmark in detection accuracy, particularly in underrepresented and challenging conditions.
AI.conclusion: Neptune-X significantly enhances maritime object detection by combining generative modeling and active sample selection, demonstrating its effectiveness for real-world applications in navigation and surveillance.

title: TSKAN: Interpretable Machine Learning for QoE modeling over Time Series Data
summary:
Quality of Experience (QoE) modeling is crucial for optimizing video
streaming services to capture the complex relationships between different
features and user experience. We propose a novel approach to QoE modeling in
video streaming applications using interpretable Machine Learning (ML)
techniques over raw time series data. Unlike traditional black-box approaches,
our method combines Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) as an interpretable
readout on top of compact frequency-domain features, allowing us to capture
temporal information while retaining a transparent and explainable model. We
evaluate our method on popular datasets and demonstrate its enhanced accuracy
in QoE prediction, while offering transparency and interpretability.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a novel interpretable QoE modeling for video streaming using Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks on frequency-domain features.
AI.motivation: The need to optimize video streaming services by accurately modeling user experience and capturing complex feature relationships.
AI.method: Utilizing Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks combined with compact frequency-domain features for interpretable QoE modeling from raw time series data.
AI.result: Enhanced accuracy in predicting QoE compared to traditional black-box methods, coupled with improved model transparency.
AI.conclusion: The study offers a clear, interpretable, and effective mechanism for QoE prediction in video streaming applications.

title: CORE: Full-Path Evaluation of LLM Agents Beyond Final State
summary:
Evaluating AI agents that solve real-world tasks through function-call
sequences remains an open challenge. Existing agentic benchmarks often reduce
evaluation to a binary judgment of the final state, overlooking critical
aspects such as safety, efficiency, and intermediate correctness. We propose a
framework based on deterministic finite automata (DFAs) that encodes tasks as
sets of valid tool-use paths, enabling principled assessment of agent behavior
in diverse world models. Building on this foundation, we introduce CORE, a
suite of five metrics, namely Path Correctness, Path Correctness - Kendall's
tau Composite, Prefix Criticality, Harmful-Call Rate, and Efficiency, that
quantify alignment with expected execution patterns. Across diverse worlds, our
method reveals important performance differences between agents that would
otherwise appear equivalent under traditional final-state evaluation schemes.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces an evaluation framework for AI agents using deterministic finite automata (DFAs) to address limitations of traditional binary final-state evaluations. A suite of metrics called CORE is proposed to assess safety, efficiency, and intermediate correctness.
AI.motivation: Existing agent evaluation methods often overlook intermediate behaviors and focus solely on the final result, neglecting aspects such as safety, intermediate correctness, and efficiency.
AI.method: The work uses deterministic finite automata (DFAs) to encode tasks as sets of valid tool-use paths. It introduces the CORE metric suite to evaluate agents on Path Correctness, Path Correctness - Kendall's tau Composite, Prefix Criticality, Harmful-Call Rate, and Efficiency.
AI.result: The framework effectively differentiates agent behaviors across diverse scenarios, exposing performance nuances that traditional final-state evaluations fail to capture.
AI.conclusion: The proposed DFA-based framework and CORE metrics offer a more comprehensive mechanism for evaluating AI agents, emphasizing safety and intermediate correctness alongside efficiency.

title: Closed-form $\ell_r$ norm scaling with data for overparameterized linear regression and diagonal linear networks under $\ell_p$ bias
summary:
For overparameterized linear regression with isotropic Gaussian design and
minimum-$\ell_p$ interpolator $p\in(1,2]$, we give a unified, high-probability
characterization for the scaling of the family of parameter norms $ \\{ \lVert
\widehat{w_p} \rVert_r \\}_{r \in [1,p]} $ with sample size.
  We solve this basic, but unresolved question through a simple dual-ray
analysis, which reveals a competition between a signal *spike* and a *bulk* of
null coordinates in $X^\top Y$, yielding closed-form predictions for (i) a
data-dependent transition $n_\star$ (the "elbow"), and (ii) a universal
threshold $r_\star=2(p-1)$ that separates $\lVert \widehat{w_p} \rVert_r$'s
which plateau from those that continue to grow with an explicit exponent.
  This unified solution resolves the scaling of *all* $\ell_r$ norms within the
family $r\in [1,p]$ under $\ell_p$-biased interpolation, and explains in one
picture which norms saturate and which increase as $n$ grows.
  We then study diagonal linear networks (DLNs) trained by gradient descent. By
calibrating the initialization scale $\alpha$ to an effective
$p_{\mathrm{eff}}(\alpha)$ via the DLN separable potential, we show empirically
that DLNs inherit the same elbow/threshold laws, providing a predictive bridge
between explicit and implicit bias.
  Given that many generalization proxies depend on $\lVert \widehat {w_p}
\rVert_r$, our results suggest that their predictive power will depend
sensitively on which $l_r$ norm is used.

AI.tldr: The paper explores the scaling behavior of $\ell_p$-biased interpolation norms for overparameterized linear regression, deriving unified predictions for norm behavior and thresholds.
AI.motivation: Understanding how parameter norms scale with sample size and determining which facets saturate versus grow is key for generalization in overparameterized models.
AI.method: The study utilizes dual-ray analysis to derive behavior predictions and investigates the dynamics in diagonal linear networks (DLNs) trained by gradient descent.
AI.result: Findings reveal an elbow transition point $n_\star$ and a universal threshold $r_\star=2(p-1)$ for norm scaling, with empirical validation in DLNs.
AI.conclusion: The insights bridge explicit and implicit biases, emphasizing the sensitive dependence of generalization proxies on chosen parameter norms.

title: Building Information Models to Robot-Ready Site Digital Twins (BIM2RDT): An Agentic AI Safety-First Framework
summary:
The adoption of cyber-physical systems and jobsite intelligence that connects
design models, real-time site sensing, and autonomous field operations can
dramatically enhance digital management in the construction industry. This
paper introduces BIM2RDT (Building Information Models to Robot-Ready Site
Digital Twins), an agentic artificial intelligence (AI) framework designed to
transform static Building Information Modeling (BIM) into dynamic, robot-ready
digital twins (DTs) that prioritize safety during execution. The framework
bridges the gap between pre-existing BIM data and real-time site conditions by
integrating three key data streams: geometric and semantic information from BIM
models, activity data from IoT sensor networks, and visual-spatial data
collected by robots during site traversal. The methodology introduces
Semantic-Gravity ICP (SG-ICP), a point cloud registration algorithm that
leverages large language model (LLM) reasoning. Unlike traditional methods,
SG-ICP utilizes an LLM to infer object-specific, plausible orientation priors
based on BIM semantics, improving alignment accuracy by avoiding convergence on
local minima. This creates a feedback loop where robot-collected data updates
the DT, which in turn optimizes paths for missions. The framework employs YOLOE
object detection and Shi-Tomasi corner detection to identify and track
construction elements while using BIM geometry as a priori maps. The framework
also integrates real-time Hand-Arm Vibration (HAV) monitoring, mapping
sensor-detected safety events to the digital twin using IFC standards for
intervention. Experiments demonstrate SG-ICP's superiority over standard ICP,
achieving RMSE reductions of 64.3%--88.3% in alignment across scenarios with
occluded features, ensuring plausible orientations. HAV integration triggers
warnings upon exceeding exposure limits, enhancing compliance with ISO 5349-1.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces BIM2RDT, an AI-based framework for transforming BIMs into robot-ready digital twins to enhance construction safety and efficiency.
AI.motivation: To address the gap between static BIM data and real-time, dynamic construction site management, especially for safety and operational optimization.
AI.method: The framework combines BIM data, IoT sensor activity, and robot-collected visual-spatial data using the SG-ICP algorithm (leveraging LLM reasoning), YOLOE object detection, and real-time Hand-Arm Vibration (HAV) monitoring.
AI.result: Experiments show SG-ICP improves accuracy significantly (64.3%--88.3% RMSE reductions) compared to traditional algorithms, and HAV monitoring enhances safety compliance.
AI.conclusion: The BIM2RDT framework successfully integrates multiple technologies to create dynamic and safety-focused digital twins for autonomous construction site operations.

title: RedHerring Attack: Testing the Reliability of Attack Detection
summary:
In response to adversarial text attacks, attack detection models have been
proposed and shown to successfully identify text modified by adversaries.
Attack detection models can be leveraged to provide an additional check for NLP
models and give signals for human input. However, the reliability of these
models has not yet been thoroughly explored. Thus, we propose and test a novel
attack setting and attack, RedHerring. RedHerring aims to make attack detection
models unreliable by modifying a text to cause the detection model to predict
an attack, while keeping the classifier correct. This creates a tension between
the classifier and detector. If a human sees that the detector is giving an
``incorrect'' prediction, but the classifier a correct one, then the human will
see the detector as unreliable. We test this novel threat model on 4 datasets
against 3 detectors defending 4 classifiers. We find that RedHerring is able to
drop detection accuracy between 20 - 71 points, while maintaining (or
improving) classifier accuracy. As an initial defense, we propose a simple
confidence check which requires no retraining of the classifier or detector and
increases detection accuracy greatly. This novel threat model offers new
insights into how adversaries may target detection models.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces the RedHerring attack, which compromises the reliability of adversarial text attack detectors by manipulating predictions, causing tension between classifier and detector.
AI.motivation: The paper seeks to explore the reliability of adversarial text attack detection models, which hasn't been thoroughly investigated, despite their importance.
AI.method: It proposes the RedHerring attack to manipulate text, ensuring detectors misidentify it as adversarial while classifiers maintain correct predictions. The attack is tested on 4 datasets using 3 detectors and 4 classifiers.
AI.result: RedHerring significantly reduces detection accuracy by 20-71 points while maintaining or improving classifier accuracy.
AI.conclusion: The RedHerring threat model highlights vulnerabilities in detection models, motivating further research, and offers a preliminary defense mechanism based on a confidence check to improve detection accuracy without retraining.

title: AI-Enabled Crater-Based Navigation for Lunar Mapping
summary:
Crater-Based Navigation (CBN) uses the ubiquitous impact craters of the Moon
observed on images as natural landmarks to determine the six degrees of freedom
pose of a spacecraft. To date, CBN has primarily been studied in the context of
powered descent and landing. These missions are typically short in duration,
with high-frequency imagery captured from a nadir viewpoint over well-lit
terrain. In contrast, lunar mapping missions involve sparse, oblique imagery
acquired under varying illumination conditions over potentially year-long
campaigns, posing significantly greater challenges for pose estimation. We
bridge this gap with STELLA - the first end-to-end CBN pipeline for
long-duration lunar mapping. STELLA combines a Mask R-CNN-based crater
detector, a descriptor-less crater identification module, a robust
perspective-n-crater pose solver, and a batch orbit determination back-end. To
rigorously test STELLA, we introduce CRESENT-365 - the first public dataset
that emulates a year-long lunar mapping mission. Each of its 15,283 images is
rendered from high-resolution digital elevation models with SPICE-derived Sun
angles and Moon motion, delivering realistic global coverage, illumination
cycles, and viewing geometries. Experiments on CRESENT+ and CRESENT-365 show
that STELLA maintains metre-level position accuracy and sub-degree attitude
accuracy on average across wide ranges of viewing angles, illumination
conditions, and lunar latitudes. These results constitute the first
comprehensive assessment of CBN in a true lunar mapping setting and inform
operational conditions that should be considered for future missions.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces STELLA, a complete pipeline for Crater-Based Navigation (CBN) crucial for long-duration lunar mapping, and validates it with a realistic dataset called CRESENT-365.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the challenges of applying Crater-Based Navigation (CBN) in long-duration lunar mapping missions, given its prior focus on short-duration lunar descent contexts.
AI.method: STELLA integrates a Mask R-CNN-based crater detector, a robust crater identification module, a pose solver, and a batch orbit determination back-end. It is tested using a new dataset, CRESENT-365, which mimics long-term lunar mapping conditions.
AI.result: STELLA achieves metre-level position and sub-degree attitude accuracies across varying conditions, including wide viewing ranges and different lighting scenarios.
AI.conclusion: STELLA demonstrates effective and reliable CBN for year-long lunar mapping missions, marking a significant advancement in the field and providing insights for future missions.

title: Explicit and Effectively Symmetric Schemes for Neural SDEs
summary:
Backpropagation through (neural) SDE solvers is traditionally approached in
two ways: discretise-then-optimise, which offers accurate gradients but incurs
prohibitive memory costs due to storing the full computational graph (even when
mitigated by checkpointing); and optimise-then-discretise, which achieves
constant memory cost by solving an auxiliary backward SDE, but suffers from
slower evaluation and gradient approximation errors. Algebraically reversible
solvers promise both memory efficiency and gradient accuracy, yet existing
methods such as the Reversible Heun scheme are often unstable under complex
models and large step sizes. We address these limitations by introducing a
novel class of stable, near-reversible Runge--Kutta schemes for neural SDEs.
These Explicit and Effectively Symmetric (EES) schemes retain the benefits of
reversible solvers while overcoming their instability, enabling
memory-efficient training without severe restrictions on step size or model
complexity. Through numerical experiments, we demonstrate the superior
stability and reliability of our schemes, establishing them as a practical
foundation for scalable and accurate training of neural SDEs.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a novel class of stable, memory-efficient, and nearly reversible Runge-Kutta solvers for neural SDEs that address instability issues in previous methods.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to improve the training of neural stochastic differential equations (SDEs) by addressing memory inefficiency, slow evaluation, and instability issues in existing solver approaches.
AI.method: It introduces Explicit and Effectively Symmetric (EES) Runge-Kutta schemes that offer stability, near-reversibility, memory efficiency, and gradient accuracy for calculating solutions to neural SDEs.
AI.result: The proposed EES schemes demonstrate superior stability and reliability in numerical experiments compared to traditional solvers, validating their practical use for scalable and efficient neural SDE training.
AI.conclusion: The novel EES schemes overcome limitations of existing methods, providing a robust foundation for the efficient and accurate training of neural SDEs without imposing strict constraints on step size or model complexity.

title: Who Gets Cited Most? Benchmarking Long-Context Language Models on Scientific Articles
summary:
This paper introduces SciTrek, a novel question-answering benchmark designed
to evaluate the long-context reasoning capabilities of large language models
(LLMs) using scientific articles. Current long-context benchmarks often rely on
non-scientific texts, focus on simple information retrieval tasks, or employ
artificial contexts. SciTrek addresses these limitations by proposing complex
questions that require information aggregation and synthesis across multiple
full-text scientific articles. Questions and their ground-truth answers are
automatically generated by formulating them as SQL queries over a database
constructed from article metadata (titles, authors, and references). The SQL
operations provide explicit, verifiable reasoning steps for fine-grained error
analysis, and the construction process scales to contexts up to 1M tokens with
minimal supervision. Extensive experiments on a diverse set of open-weight and
proprietary LLMs demonstrate that SciTrek poses a significant challenge as the
context length increases, with supervised fine-tuning and reinforcement
learning offering only limited gains. Our analysis reveals systematic
shortcomings in models' abilities to perform basic numerical operations and
accurately locate specific information in long contexts.

AI.tldr: SciTrek is a benchmark for evaluating long-context reasoning in LLMs using scientific articles, focusing on complex questions requiring information synthesis across multiple texts.
AI.motivation: Existing benchmarks for long-context reasoning often use non-scientific texts or artificial setups, hindering effective evaluation of LLMs.
AI.method: SciTrek generates complex questions and answers via SQL queries on scientific article metadata, enabling scalability to 1M tokens and fine-grained error analysis.
AI.result: Experiments reveal LLMs struggle with numerical operations and locating information in long contexts, even with fine-tuning or reinforcement learning.
AI.conclusion: SciTrek highlights significant challenges in LLMs’ long-context reasoning abilities and suggests gaps in their current capabilities.

title: Towards a user-centric HPC-QC environment
comment: 9 Pages, accepted to SFWM workshop at SC25
summary:
Robust execution environments are important for addressing key challenges in
quantum computing, such as application development, portability, and
reproducibility, and help unlock the development of modular quantum programs,
driving forward hybrid quantum workflows. In this work, we show progress
towards a basic, but portable, runtime environment for developing and executing
hybrid quantum-classical programs running in High Performance Computing (HPC)
environments enhanced with Quantum Processing Units (QPUs). The middleware
includes a second layer of scheduling after the main HPC resource manager in
order to improve the utilization of the QPU, and extra functionality for
observability, monitoring, and admin access. This approach enables managing
multiple programming Software Development Kits (SDKs) as first-class citizens
in the environment by building on a recently proposed vendor-neutral Quantum
Resource Management Interface (QRMI). Lastly, we discuss and show a solution
for the monitoring and observability stack, completing our description of the
hybrid system architecture.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a middleware for managing quantum-classical programs in HPC environments utilizing QPUs. It introduces enhanced scheduling, observability, and monitoring capabilities.
AI.motivation: The paper aims to address challenges like application development, portability, and reproducibility in quantum computing, enabling modular quantum programs and hybrid quantum workflows.
AI.method: The authors develop a middleware in HPC environments featuring secondary scheduling, monitoring, observability, and integrating multiple SDKs using the vendor-neutral QRMI interface.
AI.result: The proposed system demonstrates improved QPU utilization and provides tools for monitoring and management within hybrid quantum-classical architectures.
AI.conclusion: The work advances modular and portable quantum program execution environments within HPC frameworks, facilitating resource optimization and enhanced functionality.

title: No Prior, No Leakage: Revisiting Reconstruction Attacks in Trained Neural Networks
summary:
The memorization of training data by neural networks raises pressing concerns
for privacy and security. Recent work has shown that, under certain conditions,
portions of the training set can be reconstructed directly from model
parameters. Some of these methods exploit implicit bias toward margin
maximization, suggesting that properties often regarded as beneficial for
generalization may actually compromise privacy. Yet despite striking empirical
demonstrations, the reliability of these attacks remains poorly understood and
lacks a solid theoretical foundation. In this work, we take a complementary
perspective: rather than designing stronger attacks, we analyze the inherent
weaknesses and limitations of existing reconstruction methods and identify
conditions under which they fail. We rigorously prove that, without
incorporating prior knowledge about the data, there exist infinitely many
alternative solutions that may lie arbitrarily far from the true training set,
rendering reconstruction fundamentally unreliable. Empirically, we further
demonstrate that exact duplication of training examples occurs only by chance.
Our results refine the theoretical understanding of when training set leakage
